subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Book suggestions for translation.
msgSnippet: ... Yes, but the Universal Character Set encodes characters. ... Both ISO/IEC JTC1/SC2 and the Unicode Consortium use technical terminology. If one wishes to
messageBody:
On 30 Jul 2011, at 20:09, Terry Smithwick wrote:

> The term 'grapheme' includes all the ordinary meanings of 'character' (when referring to the written object), as well as covering items used in other languages that don't fit the ordinary meaning of 'character'.

Yes, but the Universal Character Set encodes characters.

> Within this group the more inclusive term is completely appropriate, despite the low-brow usage by the Unicode Group in it's public pages.

Both ISO/IEC JTC1/SC2 and the Unicode Consortium use technical terminology. If one wishes to discuss that standard, one should use the appropriate terminology.

> It was never stated that the 'policing' of the Personal Use area was official. And the Personal Use area is used for 'odd-ball' and unusual alphabets; what's the harm in saying so?

It's called the "Private Use Area". It can be used by anyone for anything, subject to agreement between sender and receiver. It was not purpose-created for alphabets, odd-ball or not.

> Since a QuikScript proposal for Unicode has not been accepted, stating that QS will be an extension of Shavian amounts to fortunetelling - or personal opinion. Or does your opinion have the force of law?

Having been attending WG2 meetings since 1994 I think I can say that I some knowledge of what the committees are likely to accept. QuikScript fonts are very much cursive fonts for Shavian, with some extensions. It is unlikely that the two will be disunified.

Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com/
